'''Raymond Pearl''' (3 June 1879 – 17 November 1940) was an American [[biologist]], regarded as one of the founders of [[biogerontology]]. He spent most of his career at [[Johns Hopkins University]] in [[Baltimore]].

Pearl was a prolific writer of academic books, papers and articles, as well as a committed populariser and communicator of [[science]]. At his death, 841 publications were listed against his name.

==Background==
Born of upper-middle class parents in [[New England]], Pearl excelled at school and went on to [[Dartmouth College]] where he gained his B.A. in 1899, and the [[University of Michigan]] where he gained his PhD in zoology in 1902. In 1906 he spent a year studying under [[Karl Pearson]] at [[University College, London]]. During this year he discovered [[biometry]], which seemed to offer a solution to the problems he was concerned with in biology, [[zoology]] and [[eugenics]]. On his return to the US he continued his interests, but was converted from biometry to [[Mendelian genetics]].

==Eugenics and politics==
Pearl maintained a loose interest in eugenics, but in 1927 published the landmark article ''The Biology of Superiority'', which attacked the basic assumptions of eugenics.<ref>{{Cite journal | volume = 12 | pages = 257–266 | last = Pearl | first = Raymond | title = The biology of superiority | journal = American Mercury | year = 1927 }}</ref>  The article was the first general attack on eugenics by someone perceived as being within the movement.<ref name=allan>{{Cite book | publisher = Cambridge University Press | isbn = 978-0-521-27560-6 | pages = 169‒202 | editors = Hugo Tristram Engelhardt and Arthur Leonard Caplan (eds.) | last = Allen | first = Garland E. | title = Scientific controversies: case studies in the resolution and closure of disputes in science and technology | chapter = The role of experts in scientific controversy | location = Cambridge ; New York | year = 1987 }}</ref>  It also contributed to the emergence of reform eugenics and the [[population control]] movement. Pearl was an influential member of the Advisory Committee of the [[World Population Conference]],<ref>{{cite book|last=Sanger|first=Margaret|title=Proceedings of the World Population Conference|year=1927|publisher=Edward Arnold & Co.|location=London|page=11|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=MyRBAAAAIAAJ&q=%22proceedings+of+the+world+population+conference%22&dq=%22proceedings+of+the+world+population+conference%22&hl=en&sa=X&ei=EMB6UdLgOOf94APlzoHgCA&ved=0CDIQ6AEwAA}}</ref>  after which Pearl helped found the [[International Union for the Scientific Study of Population Problems]].<ref name="allan" /><ref name=ludmerer >{{Cite journal | last1 = Ludmerer | first1 = K. M. | title = American geneticists and the eugenics movement: 1905–1935 | doi = 10.1007/BF00125023 | journal = Journal of the History of Biology | volume = 2 | issue = 2 | pages = 337–362 | year = 1969 | pmid =  | pmc = }}</ref>

Despite his apparent rejection of eugenics, Pearl maintained relatively good relations with key eugenicists<ref>{{Cite book | publisher = Oxford University Press | isbn = 978-0-19-534878-1 | last = Kühl | first = Stefan | title = The Nazi Connection: Eugenics, American Racism, and German National Socialism | location = Oxford | date = 2002-02-14 }}</ref> and expressed classist views.<ref>{{Cite book | publisher = U of Minnesota Press | isbn = 978-0-8166-3558-0 | last = Ordover | first = Nancy | title = American Eugenics: Race, Queer Anatomy, and the Science of Nationalism | year = 2003 | page = 146}}</ref> He made statements which have been interpreted as being [[anti-Semitic]].<ref>{{Cite book | publisher = Cambridge University Press | isbn = 978-0-521-45875-7 | last = Barkan | first = Elazar | title = The Retreat of Scientific Racism: Changing Concepts of Race in Britain and the United States Between the World Wars | date = 1993-09-16 | page = 216 }}</ref>  On the other hand, he worked for Black civil rights groups as an advisor.{{citation needed|date=April 2013}}

==Science==
In 1926 Pearl founded ''[[The Quarterly Review of Biology]]''.

Pearl is regarded as one of founders of [[Gerontology#Biogerontology|biogerontology]]. In 1908 Max Rubner observed that mammals of different size and [[longevity]] had equal [[mass]] specific [[metabolism|metabolic]] output.<ref>{{Cite book| first=Max | last=Rubner |  year=1908 | title=Das Problem der Lebensdauer und seine Beziehungen zum Wachstum und Ernahrung |  publisher=Oldenbourg | location=Munich, Germany}}{{Page needed|date=September 2010}}</ref> Partly based on the observation that the longevity of [[Drosophila melanogaster|fruit flies]] varies inversely with ambient temperature,<ref>{{Cite journal| author=Loeb, Jaques and Northrop,J.H. | title=On the influence of food and temperature upon the duration of life | journal=The Journal of Biological Chemistry | volume=32 | issue=1 | date=1 October 1917| pages=103–121 |url=http://www.jbc.org/cgi/reprint/32/1/103 }}</ref> Pearl (like Rubner) also asserted that [[maximum life span]] is inversely proportional to [[basal metabolic rate]]. Pearl accepted [[Alexis Carrel]]'s erroneous ideas that normal [[somatic cell]]s don't age, and that aging must therefore be due to dysfunction at the body level. Pearl speculated that lifespan was limited by vital cell components that were depleted or damaged more rapidly in animals with faster metabolisms.<ref>{{Cite book| first=Raymond | last=Pearl |  year=1928 | title=The Rate of Living, Being an Account of Some Experimental Studies on the Biology of Life Duration |  publisher=Alfred A. Knopf | location=New York}}{{Page needed|date=September 2010}}</ref> [[Denham Harman]]'s [[free-radical theory|free-radical theory of aging]] later provided a  plausible causal mechanism for Pearl's hypothesis.

The ''Rate of Living Hypothesis'' enjoyed prominence as one of the foremost [[Senescence#Theories of aging|theories of aging]] for nearly 50 years. The ''Rate of Living Hypothesis'' is undermined by the observation that a [[rat]] and a [[bat]] have similar metabolic rate, but a bat lives several times longer.<ref>{{Cite journal|author=Brunet-Rossinni AK, Austad SN |title=Ageing studies on bats: a review |journal=Biogerontology |volume=5 |issue=4 |pages=211–22 |year=2004 |pmid=15314271 |doi=10.1023/B:BGEN.0000038022.65024.d8}}</ref> More recently, further doubts have been raised on the ''Rate of Living Hypothesis'' by the demonstration that, when modern statistical methods for correcting for the effects of body size and phylogeny are employed, metabolic rate does not correlate with longevity in mammals or birds.<ref>{{Cite journal|author=de Magalhães JP, Costa J, Church GM |title=An analysis of the relationship between metabolism, developmental schedules, and longevity using phylogenetic independent contrasts |journal=The Journals of Gerontology. Series a, Biological Sciences and Medical Sciences |volume=62 |issue=2 |pages=149–60 |date=February 2007 |pmid=17339640 |pmc=2288695 |url=http://biomed.gerontologyjournals.org/cgi/pmidlookup?view=long&pmid=17339640 |format= |doi=10.1093/gerona/62.2.149}} {{Dead link|date=March 2010}}</ref> (For a critique of the ''Rate of Living Hypothesis'' see ''Living fast, dying when?''.<ref>{{Cite journal|author=Speakman JR, Selman C, McLaren JS, Harper EJ |title=Living fast, dying when? The link between aging and energetics |journal=The Journal of Nutrition |volume=132 |issue=6 Suppl 2 |pages=1583S–97S |date=June 2002 |pmid=12042467 |url=http://jn.nutrition.org/cgi/pmidlookup?view=long&pmid=12042467}}</ref>)

He also served on the board of trustees for Science Service, now known as [[Society for Science & the Public]], from 1929-1935.

==Social habits and death==
Pearl was widely known for his lust for life and his love of food, drink, music and parties.<ref name=kingsland>{{Cite journal 
| last1 = Kingsland | first1 = S. 
| title = Raymond Pearl: On the frontier in the 1920's. Raymond Pearl memorial lecture, 1983 
| journal = Human biology 
| volume = 56 
| issue = 1 
| pages = 1–18 
| year = 1984 
| pmid = 6378756
}}</ref>  He was a key member of the [[Saturday Night Club]] which also included [[H. L. Mencken]].<ref>{{Cite book | publisher = Oxford University Press | isbn = 978-0-19-983927-8 | last = Rodgers | first = Marion Elizabeth | title = Mencken:The American Iconoclast | date = 2007-09-01 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite book | publisher = Springer New York | isbn = 978-1-4614-3648-5| pages = 129–141 | editors = Alan Agresti (ed.) | last = Meng | first = Xiao-Li | author2 = Charles Rohde| author3 = Scott L. Zeger| author4 = Karen Kruse Thomas| author5 = Karen Bandeen-Roche | title = Strength in Numbers: The Rising of Academic Statistics Departments in the U. S. | chapter = Johns Hopkins University Department of Biostatistics | location = New York, NY | accessdate = 2013-04-05 | year = 2012 | chapterurl = http://link.springer.com/10.1007/978-1-4614-3649-2_10 }}</ref> [[Prohibition]] made no dent in Pearl's drinking habits (which were legendary). In 1926, his book, ''Alcohol and Longevity'',<ref>{{Cite book| first=Raymond | last=Pearl |  year=1926 | title=Alcohol and Longevity |  publisher=Alfred A. Knopf | location=New York | isbn=0-405-13615-3}}</ref> Pearl demonstrated that drinking [[alcohol]] in [[alcohol consumption and health|moderation]] is associated with greater longevity than either abstaining or drinking heavily.<ref>{{Cite book | publisher = Oxford University Press | isbn = 978-0-19-965578-6 | last = Boyle | first = Peter | author2 = Paolo Boffetta| author3 = Albert B. Lowenfels| author4 = Harry Burns| author5 = Otis Brawley| author6 = Witold Zatonski| author7 = Jürgen Rehm | title = Alcohol: Science, Policy and Public Health | date = 2013-03-07 | page = 14}}</ref> In 1938, his data and work demonstrated the negative health effects of [[Tobacco smoking|smoking tobacco]].<ref name=pearl1938>{{Cite journal | last1 = Pearl | first1 = R. | title = Tobacco Smoking and Longevity | doi = 10.1126/science.87.2253.216 | journal = Science | volume = 87 | issue = 2253 | pages = 216–217 | year = 1938 | pmid =  17813231| pmc = }}</ref><ref>{{Cite book | publisher = ABC-CLIO | isbn = 0-87436-967-3 | last = Cordry | first = Harold V. | title = Tobacco: a reference handbook | location = Santa Barbara, Calif | series = Contemporary world issues | year = 2001 }}</ref>

In November 1940 Pearl was in apparently good health and paid a visit to the [[Baltimore Zoo]]. He cut his trip short complaining of chest pains and died later that day.
